Dozens of babies with spina bifida have been spared life-limiting conditions after undergoing surgery in the womb in a procedure available on the NHS. 

Helena shared her story, having given birth to baby Mila at @uclh after the surgery. üé•: @BBCBreakfast https://t.co/mYKDUUW193 https://t.co/cMPlWVMjDF

If you‚Äôve been suffering from diarrhoea, bloating or discomfort for three weeks or more, it could be a sign of cancer.

The NHS is still here to see you safely and finding cancer early makes it more treatable. Just contact your GP practice. #HelpUsHelpYou https://t.co/QfWzIpOqIT https://t.co/Frl4GcTtmB

So far, 32 babies have benefited from the procedure since the NHS announced it would be available on the health service ‚Äî and the first surgery took place on the NHS in January 2020. 

Read more. ‚û°Ô∏è https://t.co/mYKDUUW193

The procedure involves a team of up to 30, including fetal surgeons, neurosurgeons, anaesthesiologists (one for the mother one for the baby), obstetricians, neuro-paediatric surgeons, radiologists, the scrub team, and neonatologists in case the baby needs to be delivered.

‚ÄòThe NHS are heroes because without this operation her life would be completely different.‚Äô

After being told her unborn baby had spina bifida, Helena underwent surgery in the womb with a cutting-edge procedure at 23 weeks. Mila was born three months later at @GreatOrmondSt. https://t.co/hWBy4sxfaF
